ygData.subject: PUT a resource + metadata simultaneously?

From: "spamspambakedbeansandspam" <roger.gonzalez@...>
Subject: PUT a resource + metadata simultaneously?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=425722926; y=r7ePndFao7bvArR7dP9-qx7g4s1_cCBTGQKJpCe9GNPreTA18szoCD3bt8nTiJ1IT5KBjw
X-Yahoo-Profile: spamspambakedbeansandspam
X-eGroups-Approved-By: gonga_thrash <distobj@...> via web; 23 Dec 2009 14:13:18 -0000

I'm building a HTTP document store for a public API, and
I'm trying to dete=
rmine the most RESTful scheme for a uploading a (possibly new) document and=
 associated metadata in one atomic transaction.  

It feels to me like I sh=
ould be doing a PUT, but due to the strict definition in rfc2616 section 9.=
6, it feels awkward.

My current implementation uses POST.  Let's say I wan=
t to write "vacation.jpg", a few properties, and also store an associated b=
lob of EXIF metadata.  My current hacky implementation works like this (URI=
s truncated for brevity):

POST vacation.jpg?title=3DMy%20Vacation
Content-=
type: multipart/form-data

---
Content-Disposition: form-data; name=3D"docu=
ment"
Content-type: image/jpg
...
---
Content-Disposition: form-data; name=
=3D"exif"
Content-type: application/x-exif

...

---
...
201 Created
Conten=
t-location: vacation.jpg
Content-type: application/json
{
  "document" : "v=
acation.jpg",
  "*" : "vacation.jpg?content=3D*",  // results in a multipar=
t as posted
  "basic" : "vacation.jpg?content=3Dbasic",  // the urlencoded =
query
  "exif" : "vacation.jpg?content=3Dexif"  // returns just the exif
}
=

Each of these metadata URIs supports standard PUT/GET/DELETE.  (Side note;=
 I don't love my returned entity, as the "content=3D" implementation actual=
ly supports arbitrary requesting combinations of multiple metadata entities=
.)

In any case, it all works fine, but my inclination is that I should rea=
lly provide this via PUT.  As it stands, though "GET vacation.jpg" just ret=
urns the main image/jpg document (without metadata).  This would appear to =
violate rfc2616 section 9.6, which suggests that GET should return the same=
 entity that was PUT, i.e. the multipart document.

Solving is possible, bu=
t ugly.  I can change the PUT uri to:

PUT vacation.jpg?content=3D*

which =
would have the property that the exact same URL can be used for a GET and i=
t would indeed result in the original multipart entity, and I'd rely on the=
 clause that says "a PUT request on a general URI might result in several o=
ther URIs being defined by the origin server", one of which would be the ma=
in resource, "vacation.jpg".  

Unfortunately, discovering the "vacation.jp=
g" URI would be out of band with the protocol headers (I wish there were a =
way to return content headers for each of the multipart entities sent!) and=
 would have to be in the entity returned, as above.  So now GET looks user-=
friendly, but PUT is ugly.  

It looks weird and I can see this working, bu=
t although I'm
fundamentally doing a PUT, I feel that I may be stretching t=
hings a bit with the multipart entities, and maybe I should stick with POST=
 after all given the current spec(s).

Thoughts?
